infodynamics.measures.continuous

Interface MultiInfoCalculator

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    MultiInfoCalculatorCommon, MultiInfoCalculatorKernel, MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov, MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov1, MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov2

    public interface MultiInfoCalculator

    Interface for implementations of the multi-information or integration, which may be applied to either multivariate or merely univariate continuous data. That is, it is applied to double[][] data, where the first index is observation number or time, and the second is variable number. See Tononi et al. below for the definition of multi-information/integration.

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using setProperty(String, String);
    3. Initialise the calculator using initialise(int);
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • setObservations(double[][]) for calculations based on single time-series, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to addObservations(double[][]) or addObservation(double[]), then
        3. finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average multi-information: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local multi-information values for these samples: computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • local multi-information values for a specific set of samples: computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][])
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • "G. Tononi, O. Sporns, G. M. Edelman, "A measure for brain complexity: relating functional segregation and integration in the nervous system" Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Vol. 91, No. 11. (1994), pp. 5033-5037.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static java.lang.String PROP_NORMALISE
      Property name for whether to normalise incoming values to mean 0, standard deviation 1 (default true)
      static java.lang.String SAMPLING_FACTOR_PROP_NAME
      Property name for whether to use less than 100% of the samples in making the calculation; double value for this property in 0..1 gives the proportion of values to use (default is 1 meaning all).

    • Method Detail

      • initialise

        void initialise(int dimensions)
        Initialise the calculator for (re-)use, with the existing (or default) values of parameters, with number of joint variables specified. Clears an PDFs of previously supplied observations.
        Parameters:
        dimensions - the number of joint variables to consider

      • setProperty

        void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Set properties for the calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • PROP_NORMALISE -- whether to normalise the incoming variables to mean 0, standard deviation 1, or not (default false).
        • SAMPLING_FACTOR_PROP_NAME -- whether to use less than 100% of the samples in making the calculation; double value for this property in 0..1 gives the proportion of values to use (default is 1 meaning all).
        • Any properties defined by the relevant child interfaces and classes.
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • setObservations

        void setObservations(double[][] observations)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF for the multi-information. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.

        The supplied series may be a time-series, or may be simply a set of separate observations without a time interpretation.

        Should only be called once, the last call contains the observations that are used (they are not accumulated).

        Parameters:
        observations - series of multivariate observations (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • startAddObservations

        void startAddObservations()
        Signal that we will add in the samples for computing the PDF from several disjoint time-series or trials via calls to addObservation(double[]) or addObservations(double[][]) rather than setDebug(boolean).

      • addObservation

        void addObservation(double[] observation)

        Adds a new (single) observation to update the PDFs with - is intended to be called multiple times. Must be called after startAddObservations(); call finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Note that the arrays must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Parameters:
        observation - a single multivariate observation (index is variable number)

      • addObservations

        void addObservations(double[][] observations)

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with - is intended to be called multiple times. Must be called after startAddObservations(); call finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Note that the arrays must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Parameters:
        observations - series of multivariate observations (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)

      • finaliseAddObservations

        void finaliseAddObservations()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the multi-information from the previously-supplied samples.
        Returns:
        the estimate of the multi-information
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the local values of the multi-information, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call i.e. setObservations(double[][]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[][]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local multi-information values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][] states)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the local multi-information values for each of the supplied samples in states.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in states (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Parameters:
        states - series of multivariate observations (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        Returns:
        the series of local multi-information values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        double computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int[][] newOrdering)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the multi information would look like were all time series (bar the first) reordered as per the array of time indices in newOrdering.

        The reordering array contains the reordering for each marginal variable (first index). The user should ensure that all values 0..N-1 are represented exactly once in the array reordering and that no other values are included here.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of a shuffled source series here.

        This method is primarily intended for use in #computeSignificance(int[][]) however has been made public in case users wish to access it.

        Parameters:
        newOrdering - the specific permuted new orderings to use. First index is the variable number (minus 1, since we don't reorder the first variable), second index is the time step, the value is the reordered time step to use for that variable at the given time step. The values must be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by #getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1). If null, no reordering is performed.
        Returns:
        what the average multi-info would look like under this reordering
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a resampled distribution of what the multi-information would look like, under a null hypothesis that the individual values of each variable in the samples have no relation to eachother. That is, we destroy the p(x,y,z,..) correlations, while retaining the p(x), p(y),.. marginals, to check how significant this multi-information actually was.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, we are extending that here.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int[][][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate MultiInfo calculations.

        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to permute to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of surrogate multi-info values under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a resampled distribution of what the multi-information would look like, under a null hypothesis that the individual values of each variable in the samples have no relation to eachother. That is, we destroy the p(x,y,z,..) correlations, while retaining the p(x), p(y),.. marginals, to check how significant this multi-information actually was.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, we are extending that here.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) The second index is the variable number (minus 1, since we don't reorder the first variable), Each array newOrderings[i][v] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by #getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of surrogate multi-info values under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • setDebug

        void setDebug(boolean debug)
        Set or clear debug mode for extra debug printing to stdout
        Parameters:
        debug - new setting for debug mode (on/off)

      • getLastAverage

        double getLastAverage()
        Return the multi-information last calculated in a call to computeAverageLocalOfObservations() or computeLocalOfPreviousObservations() after the previous initialise(int) call.
        Returns:
        the last computed multi-information value
